categories.name: Ancient Civilizations: Beyond Egypt and Rome

questions.clue: This ancient civilization, known for its ziggurats, was located in the region of Mesopotamia.
This Mesoamerican civilization is known for its calendar and the city of Tikal.
Known for their advanced urban planning, this civilization thrived in the Indus Valley around 2500 BCE.
This ancient civilization of the Andes is known for the archaeological site of Machu Picchu.
The Minoans, known for their palace at Knossos, thrived on this island in the Aegean Sea.
In 'Romeo and Juliet', when Juliet says, 'Parting is such sweet sorrow,' she uses this oxymoronic device.
In 'Moby-Dick', the white whale is a symbol representing this concept, which varies for each character.
In '1984', George Orwell uses 'Newspeak' to demonstrate this device, where language shapes thought.
In 'Pride and Prejudice', Jane Austen often uses free indirect discourse, a technique blending third-person narration with this type of perspective.
In 'The Great Gatsby', Fitzgerald uses the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock as an example of this device, representing unattainable dreams.
This famous physicist developed the theory of relativity, which laid the foundation for parts of quantum theory.
The principle stating that certain pairs of physical properties, like position and momentum, cannot both be known to arbitrary precision is named after this German physicist.
This fundamental particle, a major component of atoms, was first proposed by Niels Bohr to orbit the nucleus in quantized energy levels.
This fundamental concept in quantum mechanics describes how particles can exist in multiple states or places simultaneously until observed.
This paradox involves a cat that is simultaneously alive and dead, illustrating the concept of superposition in quantum mechanics.
This artist's bronze statue of David was the first unsupported standing work of bronze cast during the Renaissance.
This sculptor created the marble masterpiece 'Pietà,' housed in St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City.
Florence's famous statue of David was originally commissioned for the Cathedral of Florence but ended up in the Piazza della Signoria.
This sculptor, known for his work on the Baptistery doors of Florence, earned the nickname 'Gates of Paradise' for his bronze panels.
This lesser-known sculptor created the dramatic and dynamic 'Rape of the Sabine Women,' showcasing complex group sculpture.
This Australian marsupial spends most of its time in trees and is known for its eucalyptus leaf diet.
Native to Madagascar, this primate uses its long middle finger to extract insects from trees.
This amphibian is known for its transparent skin through which its internal organs can be seen.
Inhabiting the rivers of the Amazon Basin, this pink-colored cetacean is a species of river dolphin.
This rarely seen deep-sea fish has a transparent head and tubular eyes to help it see in the dark ocean depths.

final.clue: This 1922 novel features a protagonist who is a Leopold Bloom, an Irish Jew navigating a single day in Dublin.
